commentBody:
"What did you talk to the pain specialist about?"
"Well, it's kind of a sore subject."

("Yeah, that aches sense.")

Kate Hawkins is quickly becoming one of my favorite constructors.  As always, the puzzle gave some pushback, but in the end, nothing was too out there, and it all came together in a Friday-ish time.

It didn't hurt that the answer to 1A seemed (and, in retrospect, was) very obvious to me.  Those two chains are perfect examples of what FAST CASUAL is supposed to mean.

Was this a FASTCASUAL Friday?
Did it take an unusual number of KEYSTROKES?
FARLEFT was on the far left. HAHA.

TELLMEMORE? TRYTHIS: ITSYOURLUCKYDAY.

Thanks, Kate.

Kate was cooking with gas here. 

ITSYOURLUCKYDAY? KISSEDBUTT?? TELLMEMORE???

Love seeing a constructor use their CREATIVELICENSE for a banger puzzle like this!!
I don't love the two separate "laughing sound" clues, but that's my only nitpick. Great Friday puzzle--vigorous but not too difficult.
Natick with AUDRELORDE and ADU. Fortunately it was the only square I was unsure of, so I could brute force it. My first thought was Audre Lorre and Alternative Residential Unit
Lots to like here, but I kind of feel like ADU and AKEE shouldn‚Äôt be fill in the 15x15 grid. (I have yet to figure out what ADU is short for.)

One fun thing about doing puzzles a lot: because it's Friday, I saw Athens and "probably the one in Georgia" immediately leapt up.

Sometimes I'm so used to twisty clueing that I overthink Monday ones..

Nice Friday that gave me a good workout.  Not much in my wheelhouse except for PADDINGTON and the alcohol clues (MES, MOJITOS).  The NW was especially difficult for me despite getting ITSYOURLUCKYDAY pretty quickly (apparently it wasn‚Äôt).  I didn‚Äôt see FAIR for upright, tried UCSD instead of SDSU, and couldn‚Äôt get Chevy out of my mind for Malibu.  I felt pretty sheepish when it came together because my parents owned a Malibu back in the 70s and I spent a lot of time in San Diego over the last decade.
Anyone else have "Waist" for "Watch this space!" crossing "HAA" for "Very. Funny."
CREATIVE LICENSE would make a dandy title for this brisk Friday workout, which I have filled but haven't finished at 21 min; just flyspecking left.
Watch this space -- it took me quite a while to figure this out.

A fair amount of unguessable proper nouns here, like AUDRE LORD, MES as clued, Sony's PSP, MONTERO, along with relatively obscure words like AKEE.  I beat my Friday average, but I can see how some might really struggle.
Got it, but not thrilled with a number of clues. And I thought it was "ackee".

A PSP in the ADU and TOM will never leave
and go back to UGA.

SORESUBJECT crossed with BUTT reminds me of my 
first MS150 bike ride.

A FAIR game with plenty of GUILE.

Thanks, Kate!

Naticked by 54A crossing both 3D and 9D. I've never heard of either the poem or the observatory (or the term ADU, for that matter). On top of which, the phrase FAST CASUAL is new to me, and I just don't see how FAIR is related to Upright. Oh - almost forgot: LECHE didn't make sense to me, because caf√© is a French word (we do French here in Canada, not Spanish).  

That whole NW corner was a complete mess for way too long.

Not to mention (but of course I will) the crossing of a rapper's given name at 42D with an artist. Since you only need 1 hand to count the paintings I know the title of, I figured 47A could've been either MaNET or MONET, and both MONTERO and MaNTERO sound equally likely names to my ear. As it happened, my first guess was right, but if I'd gone the other way, it's only one letter that I'd have to change.

Poor Hercules. He slays the Nemean lion. Dispatches the Hydra (lots of work, that one‚Äîgood grief, all those heads), starts capturing beasts far-left and right, cleans out some stables, then more slaying, then more capturing‚Ä¶ oof. Finally, he drags Cerberus out of Hades, settles in for his lunch break and‚Äîof course: he‚Äôs called back for overtime. Labor #13, the Subduing of Trythis. 

Trythis, a shapeshifting eel-terrier hybrid raised by elves and rogue CEOs used to serve mojitos in Thessaloniki but now she‚Äôs grabbing elk by the wrists outside a Chipotle in Athens, right off US-78 W to Atlanta. 

The historical sources are scarce, contradictory. Tacitus (in Dialogus, apocryphal appendix) redacts the whole affair. Herodotus footnotes it as ‚Äúa sore subject.‚Äù Livy? He dismisses it entirely‚Äî‚Äúcreative license gone amok.‚Äù

Hercules orders a Chipotle bowl. He‚Äôs tired. More than a little teed off. Sure enough, faster that you can say Fair Labor Standards Act violation, Trythis grips his wrist. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs your lucky day,‚Äù she hisses. 

‚ÄúTell me more,‚Äù Hercules says, mistaking guile for flirtation. They ride westward in a dented Malibu, then swerve down a side street past the Acropolis. A party with Artemis goes catastrophically wrong. Trythis bites three demigods and eats the olives.

Eventually, Hercules gifts her cement boots‚Äînot as punishment, but to keep her from floating off when she dreams. Athens exhales. Somewhere, a terrier barks, and Herodotus sighs, ‚ÄúWell. It could have happened.‚Äù

That was a fun one - and not too tough. Finished at 15 minutes on the button. 

Any time I see TELLMEMORE, I immediately think of Martin Prince playing the My Dinner With Andre video game in an early Simpsons episode. (The other joystick options are ‚Äútrenchant insight‚Äù and ‚Äúbon mot.‚Äù)
24D is definitely misspelled. It should be ACKEE. I‚Äôm grew up there and have never seen it spelled without the C.

Calif. school that runs AUTOshop

I just flew in from Natick City in Northwest Acronym/ ProperName and boy are my brains tired

I was worried after yesterday's puzzle, but I flew through this one. There were lots of gimmes for me, starting with 1A FAST CASUAL. (I learned the term while managing the accounting department of a fast casual BBQ joint in San Francisco.) Loved the queer sensibility of AUDRE LORDE and MONTERO. PADDINGTON, CREATIVE LICENSE, and KEYSTROKE were others that came to me instantly. Any answers I didn't know (AKEE, ADU, MES, UGA) filled in easily from crosses. And yet... No finished message! I guess this is what happens when I move too fast. Took a while to notice I had SfSU instead of SDSU and HAh/WhIST (which makes no sense) instead of HAR/WRIST. Instead of methodically checking all my answers, I focused on the ones I hadn't known, assuming I'd made a mistake on one of those. Nope. Anyway, while a lot the answers were fun, I do wish some of the clues had been less straightforward. Of course, YMMV. If you're wondering why HEDY Lamarr is called the mother of Wi-Fi, here's the fascinating story. I had no idea she was anything more than an actress. https://www.womenshistory.org/education-resources/biographies/hedy-lamarr

I needed lookups of the many names, trivia and abbreviations to get some crosses going. 

My heart sank right at the start of my first across pass, when having been primed for failure by the clue referencing fastfood joints I encountered the long entry of a poet's name. The only LORDE I know is a poet, in a way, but she was born in 1996 so she can't have written a poem in 1978 ü§£. Then *of course* there was a brand, a golfer, a sport team member name, what turned out to be a college, a rapper's real name, several abbreviations... All in all a kick in my Polish nuts. 

In Jamaica I ate AcKEE and saltfish. I suppose there may be spelling variants, but using the less common one always feels like a cheap trick in Crosslandia.

What's ADU? 

Is CEE ('First in command') a chief executive officer?

I resorted to revealing an entry in the end. I could not understand "watch this space" (I only got it as I was writing this), and I will never, ever remember HAR may mean a laugh in American English. It does not look or sound like any laugh I have heard in my life. I seem to remember it's a Three Stooges thing? I watched something by them once and found them painfully unfunny. I also didn't get the clue or the answer of KEY STROKES. What loggers are meant there? Well, anyway, with a few blanks there I made guesses in pencil, but I did not get my star, so I started revealing squares, and yeah, it was HA(R)/W(R)IST.

As you realize by now, this was not an enjoyable solve for me.

ADU, Accessory Dwelling Unit, is the little building where you keep your best loved hats, scarves, gloves, etc.‚Äîsometimes necklaces, earrings, neckties, tiaras and boas. Shoes always get a kick out of visiting, but there is so much that I can hardly get my TOE in the door.  (You have no idea how much MONET all this cost.)
How is "Gotcha!" I SEE?

This felt a little more challenging than most recent Fridays. I‚Äôve heard the term FAST CASUAL before but it didn‚Äôt immediately come to mind. (The nearest Chipotle is about 100 miles from me; the nearest Panera is over 160 miles away. And that‚Äôs not the sort of restaurant I prefer anyway.)

I didn‚Äôt recognize the AUDRE LORDE title and putting her name in based on the letters I had didn‚Äôt seem to work until I remembered SDSU (I think I earlier tried UCSD).

Blanking on MOJITO didn‚Äôt help. I don‚Äôt believe I have ever heard anyone say KISS BUTT; it‚Äôs usually a bit coarser than that. 

Otherwise, my solving experience was pretty smooth. There are lots of clever or amusing clues. 

Thanks for the fun, Ms Hawkins!

Shoutout to any fellow SDSU ALUMS out there. 

Double shout out if your diploma is signed by Arnold Schwarzenegger. It was a good time to be 22 and living in San Diego.

Never heard of ADUs. 

Here we‚Äôd call that a granny flat ‚Äî a flat (ie apartment) where granny might live when she needs to be nearby (either for free babysitting or because she‚Äôs getting on a bit I suppose). Though occupants need not be grannies! Grownup children or AirBnBs probably at least as common these days

Had to enter CREATIVE LICENSE through gritted teeth. I mean, hardly anyone over here spells it properly these days either, but I reserve the right to be pedantic. Would you take some advise from someone? Or would you take some advice?

Don't worry everyone, I'm fully aware that's the official spelling in Americaland, language evolves, yada yada, my beef is with someone several hundred years ago, not you ;-)

Near the end, I had 2 answers that didn't look right.  AUfRE LORDE at 14A , and WhIST at 52D.  I quickly saw that the school must be SDSU, but had to test a few letters in my head to get to WRIST.   Great clue!
Missed opportunity for "carleft". Just saying.
Would M_NTERO / M_NET be sort of a limited Natick?  Like a Dedham maybe?

A fitting end to a week of Fa√´rie. Here's a song about a trio of Jamaican fruit, with or without the "C"s--why? I have no idea: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b8igW5ah_EE Now tell me that doesn't make you smile!

HAR dee har har.

at the Mini, too.

Both puzzles felt rather tortured, stretched on the rack.

Perhaps caffeine will make me more sanguine.

An Audre Lorde puzzle is a good puzzle.

And I get the WRIST wordplay‚Ä¶

But, can someone please explain HAR to a thicko?

This was great.

It took me all the way to 24A to get my first word, which was not a confidence booster, but it was full of challenging clues that were rewarding upon success.

As a longtime housing advocate I was glad to see ADU. I am more used to seeing AcKEE spelled with the C, but in fairness I can't claim that that was why it was one of the last ones to fall for me.

By the time I had found CREATIVE, I had some crosses on the right that were wrong, so I never thought of LICENSE again until the very end! (Which finally allowed me to get those crosses right.) So close, yet so far away!

‚ÄúI‚Äôm suffering from GYM TOE.‚Äù

I'm not sure which is worse, accessory dwelling unit or referring to it as an ADU. In the first case it's pretentious, and in the second it suggests, to me at least, that we've gone overboard with abbreviations.

Not enough side streets in this one for me.

The sore subject of olden-style puzzles full of letter-groupings I don‚Äôt want to know (ADU, SDSU, UGA, HAHA, HAR) just to get names I‚Äôll never remember also crossing with (which suit?) is now brought up.

As for WRIST - being a user of cringeily-obscure word ‚Äúplay‚Äù I can‚Äôt throw stones on this one, but others should feel free.

Beat me, but didn‚Äôt crush me.

Whenever I see a clue like [1/48 cup], I am reminded of an incident at work: a former chef asked a co-worker to prepare something--biscuits, perhaps--and gave her a recipe*, which she then had to multiply by 22. The original recipe contained an ingredient--baking soda, say--with an amount of 1 tsp. Now 22 tsp. is as close to 21 tsp. as no matter, which is 7 tbsp, which is 3.5 fl.oz., or 1/2 c. minus 1 tbsp. (To be totally accurate, 1/2 c.-1 T+1t.) In other words, a scant half cup. Which is how I would have measured it. But no, I watched her measure out twenty-two individual teaspoons of baking soda. Now repeat that with the salt, the sugar, all the other ingredients. I considered giving her some advice, but I didn't really like her, so I enjoyed watching her struggle,

*I hate it when chefs pull recipes off the internet and expect them to work: first off, many of them are not very well tested. More importantly, home recipes often don't work very well in a professional kitchen, and vice versa. Chefs do that more often than one would think.
Watch this space.....head slap. Lol. Good puzzle. Loved fast casual.

The problem with WRIST, aside from being a very obscure pun, is that WAIST can work almost as well both across and down there. I actually think WAIST is a better answer, and HAA seemed weird but reasonable. Also far too many "plug" words, and after yesterday's masterpiece this one fell completely flat.
Love it. Had to scroll down to see the WRIST pun

Part obstacle course, part garden of beauty, the ideal Friday terrain.

Escape room spots where I clawed and scraped, just what my brain aches for, plus ‚ÄúOh, how gorgeous!‚Äù moments that make me happy to be alive.  Joys of Crosslandia.

Sweet answers: TELL ME MORE, CREATIVE LICENSE, SIDE STREET, FACET, TRY THIS, ASK FOR HELP, FAST CASUAL, IT‚ÄôS YOUR LUCKY DAY, SORE SUBJECT.  Those last four, by the way, are worthy NYT answer debuts, sparking the grid.  

Moments where my face screwed up as I tried to crack a clue:
‚Ä¢	A think-pause as I wondered what four-letter sylvan areas a cabin might be found in.  Big ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù when SEMI became clear.
‚Ä¢	A standstill as I explored [Watch this space!], thinking ads, gaps, even the cosmos.  Then a further juncture after the crosses revealed WRIST, as I sought to crack the clue/answer connection, and when it came ‚Äì The wit!  The wordplay! ‚Äì standing-O stellar.

A splendid outing from your hand, Kate.  Thank you, and enthusiastic thumbs up!
Upper left was tough. I was strongly tempted to look up The Black Unicorn poet, but resisted and ultimately prevailed!  Whew

Have checked and re-checked this puzzle. Even "cheated" and looked at the answer key. I am sure I've solved it correctly. This is worse than my experience on Wednesday when I had to do the puzzle three times. Did it twice, and when I came back to check the puzzle was blank, Very frustrating.
This broke my 56 day (no lookups) streak. Ouch!  14A and 9D were my demise. EXTREMELY DIFFICULT.
really enjoyed today! thanks!

WRIST is funny, but it was masked by HAR for me (I was able to convince myself that there was a WHIST joke I wasn't getting). Then the SORESUBJECT that I do tend to get Manet and MONET wrong, and here the vowel in question was resolved by... a name I didn't know that could use either vowel. That's how Friday puzzles go!

The Northwest Corner is killing me.
I understand that Fridays and saturdays are supposed to be head-scratchers, but I have a problem with any puzzle that has one segment that is considerably trickier than the rest of the puzzle.

(I also can‚Äôt stand run-on sentences, but I use them all the time‚Ä¶)

After reading yesterday's comments, I feel the need to offer this PSA about replying to replies for the foreseeable future.  Yesterday, I noticed at least one comment that was a reply to someone whose post wasn't in the visible comments, because she was addressed by name.

The recent glitch has resulted in comments being invisible if they are a reply to a previous reply in the thread, and not the original comment.  I say "invisible" because they are there if you know how to find them.  Someone discovered a few weeks ago that if you click the time stamp--the thing that says, e.g., 8m ago--of the ORIGINAL post of the thread, you can see all the replies.  But you can't see the hidden ones unless you go through that rigamarole.  What's more, when you're done and click out of it, you are sent back to the beginning of the comments, not the place you were at.

The solution is for everyone who wants to reply to a previous reply to instead reply to the original post.  You can then replace that commenter's name in the @ line with the name you're actually replying to.

A while back, frequent commenters noticed that their short posts--not everyone's, and not consistently--were not appearing.  So people learned to add additional nonsense to the end of posts just to get them through.  And it worked.  And eventually, the NYT fixed the problem.

I hope that this current glitch will be resolved soon, as well.  But until then, please use the workaround, or your post may not show up.

Weird mix of gimmes and total obscurities today.
Straight in with AUDRE LORDE, but no idea about FAST CASUAL above. What does that mean?
Likewise HEDY Lamarr was a gimme, but the neatly juxtaposed MONTERO Lamar Hill was a heartsink.
Got on to my thoughtless BrE error with CREATIVE LICENcE early, but the HAR/WRIST cross is still meaningless to me.

The association between FAR LEFT and [Uber-progressives] presumably makes sense in the American political lexicon, but was very hard for me to see, even with multiple crosses.

I could go on, but you get the picture. Lucky to get away with this one.

(2nd try)

Since I use HAA! to indicate something is funny, and WAIST is a perfectly fine response to "Watch this space!" I'm calling my puzzle correct. After all, I correctly filled the NW portion without knowing AUDRELORDE, ADU or MES, so I think my decision is quite FAIR.

Do folks actually use HAR? In a manner that corresponds to "Very. Funny."?
Oh geez. I JUST got ‚Äúwrist.‚Äù  [eyeroll]
Nope. Not enjoyable.  Audre Lorde crossing ADU, and an absolutely awful clue for Wrist don‚Äôt make for a fun Friday.

Given that I would never read any poem, novel, article, script, or even doggerel entitled "The Black Unicorn," I did well to suss out 14A.  
I wonder how many of us went aground guessing UCSD at first.
Was "quinquennial" in there to confound us or just dress up the moth-eaten entry?
Aaaand...then there's 54A.  A single HAR?  I believe HAH might be more likely, but then WHIST was quite unlikely.  So, meh.
Not to mention
AKEE....
ADU (?auxiliary dwelling unit?  The short 'good-bye'?)

I was involved with vehicles for most of my life, and spent quite a bit of time in race car transporters and truck stops.  Not once, ever, did I ever hear anyone refer to any area as a cabin.  Never.  The common term for the sleeping area is berth or sometimes rack.  And the area in front of it is the cab, which may have come years ago from cabin but even if it did has fallen out of use before all of us were born.  This was standard from coast to coast. You could draw up lists of all the words you know and all the pop culture, geography, slang, and history, and anything else you have picked up here and there and give them to a constructor to make a puzzle you can solve without so much trouble. Then you would say it was "too easy" or "lazy" or "wrong for the day," or whatever.

Calling out clues and fills in the puzzle that are factually wrong is great.  But insulting a constructor for clues that made you think and have to PUZZLE OUT what they meant is not.

I wonder: how often do you actually spell out what a letter sounds like, in English?

I don't think I have ever seen the individual sounds of letters spelled out in writing in Polish. Actually, I'm sure I have not. How can I be sure? Well, I was in my late 20s when I met my future wife. I come from Warsaw in Mazowsze (Mazovia), and she hails from another part of the country. Only after months of listening to one another did we realize there are minor differences in our Polish. Among them was how differently we pronounce the letter "e" after a consonant, especially after "g", as in the name Genia (diminutive of Genowefa, Genevieve). When I say it, it sounds as it were spelled Gienia [hard G as in gun; followed by "yeah" and "nyah": G-yeah-nya]. When my wife says it, it sounds as it is literally spelled, without that additional soft "i" after the G. So my wife's Genia sounds like [G-Enya: that's the hard G again, and the artist Enya].

So, apparently, were I to spell out the G sound, it would be "gie" (in Polish, so probably gyeah in English), but for my wife it would be "ge".

ADU = Accessory Dwelling Unit.
Big deal these days in California.  The state government passed a law a few years ago that any property zoned for a single family house could also have up to 3 ADUs!    Some 'exclusive' cities are still having fits and involved in lawsuits.

We bought our home in 1975, and it already had an ADU because it was built in 1947 before the area was part of any city -- just rural farmland.  Yes, rural farmland in the heart of what is now Silicon Valley.  But we had to get a letter from Palo Alto City to give to the bank to get our loan stating that the ADU was allowed because it was built pre-zoning.

Now the 1950's tract houses in our neighborhood are being knocked down so mini-mansions can be built,  as there is no empty land for miles around.  Every one of the new homes has an ADU.
